author: shinayser
body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I was trying to find a dll file inside my powershell folder so I did:

`cd  C:\Program Files\WindowsApps\Microsoft.PowerShell_7.2.1.0_x64__8wekyb3d8bbwe` //or whatever is your powershell folder

`ls | Select-String dll`



### Expected behavior
It is a big log but here are some of the expected behavior:

```console
-a---          13/12/2021    21:26         350320 System.Transactions.Local.dll

```

As you cann see, it should be printing every line containing a `dll` word.

comments.author: 237dmitry
comments.body:
Because you try to select string in object.
```
Get-Childitem $PSHome | Out-String -Stream | Select-String 'dll'
```

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
ls has given `select-string` a list of files to look in to find the text "dll" .  Because things which look like linebreaks are quite widely spaced in compiled files you'll get quite a lot of output, so if pwsh has references to  system.web.dll you might get the whole of pwsh.exd 

If don't want to do 

`ls *.dll`
or 
`ls | ? name -match dll`
you need to do `ls | out-string` to turn the results from files into text.

comments.author: shinayser
comments.body:
Iteresting... I am starting my studies about powershell right now and I had no idea about those objects and stuff.

So basically the problem is that instead of passing a string list to the Select-String, is that I passed a list of files...nice, thanks for the info folks!

comments.author: shinayser
comments.body: @jhoneill if you allow me one final question? How can I know the return type of a command (wether it is a lsit of files or a string, for example)?

comments.author: jhoneill
comments.body:
> @jhoneill if you allow me one final question? How can I know the return type of a command (wether it is a lsit of files or a string, for example)?

Sure. 
PowerShell commands generally don't print strings, they return objects, and PowerShell has some rules for how to convert them for display.  The `Get-Member` command (alias gm) shows you the type name and the properties and methods available so  `ls | gm` shows you `System.IO.FileInfo` and/or `System.IO.DirectoryInfo` 

If you do `Get-FormatData System.IO.FileInfo` it shows you the info for displaying files and directories.  ` (Get-FormatData System.IO.FileInfo).FormatViewDefinition` shows there are two table views (the first one is the default view) and there is a list and a wide format view

```
Name                 Control
----                 -------
children             System.Management.Automation.TableControl
childrenWithHardlink System.Management.Automation.TableControl
children             System.Management.Automation.ListControl
children             System.Management.Automation.WideControl
```

you can drill into it like this `(Get-FormatData System.IO.FileInfo).FormatViewDefinition[0].control.rows.columns` 
and see how the columns are selected. It means you can do stuff with the results of a cmdlet without having to parse text, and if you don't like the display style, you can replace it with your own format data.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
This is a very sad situation.
Dup #16634

title: Weird output from ls and Select-String on 7.2.1
